page.title: 09BRITISH GYPSUM-INDUSTRY
page.content: On Beacon Hill there is a{gypsum} works owned by British Gypsum. Gypsum was formed under the sea, it can be white or pink. At Beacon Hill it was quarried between the early 1800's and 1936. The site is 100 acres in size. Today most of the {quarries}have been filled in and the land is farmed. The old quarries are also used as rifle ranges and rubbish tips. Today white gypsum from the quarries at Hawton is processed. It is taken by lorry to the Beacon Hill site where it is crushed, ground, heated and made into {plaster}. 80 men are employed there now. The plant works night and day. The plaster is used in the medical profession for making plaster bandages, and in the pottery industry where it is used to make plaster casts and models.
